definitions.definition: to fill or use a space, an area or an amount of time

examples.text: The bed seemed to occupy most of the room.
As the company grew, it continued to occupy more space.
Administrative work occupies half of my time.
How do you occupy your time?
Their time is fully occupied with their rigorous training regime.

definitions.definition: to live or work in a room, house or building

examples.text: He occupies an office on the 12th floor.

definitions.definition: to enter a place in a large group and take control of it, especially by military force

examples.text: The capital has been occupied by the rebel army.
Protesting students occupied the TV station.

definitions.definition: to fill your time or keep you busy doing something
definitions.sensetop: occupy somebody/something/yourselfoccupy somebody/something/yourself with somebody/somethingoccupy somebody/something/yourself (in) doing something

examples.text: a game that will occupy the kids for hours
Problems at work continued **to occupy his mind** for some time.
She occupied herself with routine office tasks.
She occupied herself doing routine office tasks.

definitions.definition: to have an official job or position

examples.text: The president occupies the position for four years.
jobs that have traditionally been occupied by men

wordOrigin: Middle English: formed irregularly from Old French occuper, from Latin occupare ‘seize’. A now obsolete vulgar sense ‘have sexual relations with’ seems to have led to the general avoidance of the word in the 17th and most of the 18th cent.
